CarePlan.copyright: InterQual® Coordinated Care Disclaimer: InterQual Coordinated Care (“ICC”) enables users to reference the InterQual content as they conduct assessments, generate care plan outputs, and related content to support care management. While CHC provides ICC as a tool, CHC is not responsible for the care plan itself or any related output that users generate or prepare using ICC. Customers are solely responsible for ICC and are responsible for using all such output in accordance with professional judgement. CHC is not engaged in the practice of medicine, and NEITHER THE ICC SUBSCRIPTION NOR ANY OTHER SERVICE PROVIDED UNDER THIS AGREEMENT CONSTITUTES medical advice OR a TOOL FOR MEDICAL DIAGNOSIS.

Question.Desc: Reason that advance directive is not appropriate or refused:

Bathing: either sponge bath, tub bath, or shower

ChoiceEle.Desc: Receives no assistance (gets in and out of tub by self if tub is usual means of bathing)
Receives assistance in bathing only one part of the body (such as back or a leg)
Receives assistance in bathing more than one part of the body (or not bathed)

Question.Desc: Dressing: gets clothes from closets and drawers including underclothes, outer garments and using fasteners (including braces if worn)

ChoiceEle.Desc: Gets clothes and gets completely dressed without assistance
Gets clothes and gets dressed without assistance except for assistance in tying shoes
Receives assistance in getting clothes or in getting dressed, or stays partly or completely undressed

Question.Desc: Toileting: going to the "toilet room" for bowel and urine elimination, cleaning self after elimination, and arranging clothes

ChoiceEle.Desc: Goes to "toilet room," cleans self, and arranges clothes without assistance (may use object for support such as cane, walker, or wheelchair and may manage night bedpan or commode, emptying same in morning)
Receives assistance in going to "toilet room" or in cleansing self or in arranging clothes after elimination or in use
Doesn't go to room termed "toilet" for the elimination process
Moves in and out of bed as well as in and out of chair without assistance (may be using object for support such as cane or walker)
Moves in and out of bed or chair with assistance
Controls urination and bowel movement completely by self
Supervision helps keep urine or bowel control; catheter
Feeds self except for getting assistance in cutting meat or buttering bread
Receives assistance in feeding or is fed partly or completely by using tubes or intravenous fluids

Question.Desc:
ADL Index of Independence
Score of 6 = A-Independent in feeding, continence, transferring, going to toilet, dressing, and bathing.

ADL Index of Independence
Score of 5 = B-Independent in all but one of these functions.

ADL Index of Independence
Score of 4 = C-Independent in all but bathing and one additional function.

ADL Index for Independence
Score of 3 = D-Independent in all but bathing, dressing, and one additional function.

ADL Index of Independence
Score of 2 = E-Independent in all but bathing, dressing, going to toilet, and one additional function.

ADL Index of Independence
Score of 1= F-Independent in all but bathing, dressing, going to toilet, transferring, and one additional function.

ADL Index of Independence
Score of 0 = G-Dependent in all six functions.

ADL Index of Independence
Other Score-Dependent in at least two functions, but not classifiable as C,D,E, or F.
Ability to use telephone

ChoiceEle.Desc: Operates telephone on own initiative—looks up and dials numbers, etc.
Answers telephone but does not dial
Does not use telephone at all
Takes care of all shopping needs independently
Needs to be accompanied on any shopping trip

Question.Desc: Food Preparation

ChoiceEle.Desc: Plans, prepares and serves adequate meals independently
Prepares adequate meals if supplied with ingredients
Heats and serves prepared meals, or prepares meals but does not maintain adequate diet
Needs to have meals prepared and served
Maintains house alone or with occasional assistance (e.g., "heavy work-domestic help")
Performs light daily tasks such as dishwashing, bedmaking
Performs light daily tasks but cannot maintain acceptable level of cleanliness
Needs help with all home maintenance tasks
Does not participate in any housekeeping tasks
Launders small items rinses socks, stockings, etc.
All laundry must be done by others

Question.Desc: Mode of Transportation

ChoiceEle.Desc: Travels independently on public transportation or drives own car
Arranges own travel via taxi, but does not otherwise use public transportation
Travels on public transportation when assisted or accompanied by another
Travel limited to taxi or automobile with assistance of another

Question.Desc: Responsibility for own Medications

ChoiceEle.Desc: Is responsible for taking medication in correct dosages at correct time
Takes responsibility if medication is prepared in advance in separate dosages
Is not capable of dispensing own medication

Question.Desc: Ability to Handle Finances

ChoiceEle.Desc: Manages financial matters independently (budgets, writes checks, pays rent, bills, goes to bank), collects and keeps track of income
Manages day-to-day purchases, but needs help with banking, major purchases, etc.

Question.Desc: IADL Score
Member can learn, remember, concentrate, make decisions and communicate clearly without assistance

I would like to ask you some questions that ask you to use your memory. I am going to name three objects. Please wait until I say all three words, then repeat them. Remember what they are because I am going to ask you to name them again in a few minutes. "Apple, Table, Penny"
NOTE: Did member correctly repeat all three words?
What year is this?
What month is this?
What is the day of the week?

What were the three objects I asked you to remember?
NOTE: Only check those items that could NOT be remembered.

Question.Desc: Age is >= 65 years old

Diagnosis (3 or more co-existing)
-Includes only documented medical diagnosis.

Prior history of falls within 3 months
-An unintentional change in position resulting in coming to rest on the ground or at a lower level.

Incontinence
-Inability to make it to the bathroom or commode in timely manner; includes frequency, urgency, and/or nocturia.

Visual impairment
-Includes but not limited to, macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathies, visual field loss, age related changes, decline in visual acuity, accommodation, glare tolerance, depth perception, and night vision or not wearing prescribed glasses or having the correct prescription.

Impaired functional mobility
-May include patients who need help with IADLS or ADLS or have gait or transfer problems, arthritis, pain, fear of falling, foot problems, impaired sensation, impaired coordination or improper use of assistive devices.

Environmental hazards
-May include but not limited to, poor illumination, equipment tubing, inappropriate footwear, pets, hard to reach items, floor surfaces that are uneven or cluttered, or outdoor entry and exits.

Poly Pharmacy (4 or more prescriptions – any type)
-All PRESCRIPTIONS including prescriptions for OTC meds. Drugs highly associated with fall risk include but not limited to, sedatives, anti-depressants, tranquilizers, narcotics, antihypertensives, cardiac meds, corticosteroids, anti-anxiety drugs, anticholinergic drugs, and hypoglycemic drugs.

Pain affecting level of function
-Pain often affects an individual’s desire or ability to move or pain can be a factor in depression or compliance with safety recommendations.

Cognitive impairment
-Could include patients with dementia, Alzheimer’s or stroke patients or patients who are confused, use poor judgment, have decreased comprehension, impulsivity, memory deficits. Consider patients ability to adhere to the plan of care.

Is medication that is FDA-approved to treat ADHD prescribed?
Do you take any of the following types of NSAIDs (except cardioprotective aspirin)?

ChoiceEle.Desc: Prescriptive strength NSAIDs on a regular basis
Over-the-counter NSAIDs on a regular basis
Over-the-counter NSAIDs on an occasional basis

Question.Desc: When was the last time you had a complete blood count (CBC) test?
When was the last time you had a liver function test?
When was the last time you had a kidney function (blood) test?
Have you had an HCV viral load test in the last month?
Have you had an HBV viral load test in the last 6 months?
Have you had an INR test to monitor your warfarin?

ChoiceEle.Desc: Yes - As prescribed or recommended by provider
No, clinician to contact provider, member unwilling or unable

Question.Desc: Have you had a blood test to check factor amounts within the last year?
Have you had an electrolyte (sodium, chloride, and potassium) blood test in the last 12 months?
Have you had an inhibitor level blood test within the last year?
When was the last time you had lithium levels done?
Which self-care skills do you need more information about so you can better manage your condition?

ChoiceEle.Desc: Deciding what to eat and following a meal plan with diabetes
Identifying and avoiding exposure to triggers
Needs a written Asthma Action Plan
Understanding chronic kidney disease nutrition recommendations
Understanding how to manage diabetes during pregnancy
Understanding the effects of physical activity on blood glucose

Question.Desc: Are you monitoring, or do you need help monitoring your blood pressure as recommended?

ChoiceEle.Desc: Yes, I follow my healthcare provider's recommendations for blood pressure monitoring
No, I do not follow my healthcare provider's recommendations for blood pressure monitoring
My healthcare provider has not given me recommendations to monitor my blood pressure

Question.Desc: Have you gained 3 or more pounds overnight or 5 or more pounds in the last week?

ChoiceEle.Desc: Yes - 5 or more pounds in last week

Question.Desc: Is your provider aware of your sudden weight gain?

ChoiceEle.Desc: No - but member has written instructions on increasing diuretic dose as needed
No or Don't Know, and member agrees to contact provider
No or Don't know, and member unwilling to contact provider (Nurse to contact provider)

Question.Desc: If oxygen is prescribed for you, do you have problems using it as often as your provider has told you to?
Are you dependent on oxygen at all times, even at rest?
If peak flow monitoring is prescribed for you, do you use it just like your provider told you to?

ChoiceEle.Desc: No peak flow meter monitoring prescribed

Question.Desc: Which coping or problem solving skills do you need more information about so you can better manage your condition?
As you try to manage and live with diabetes, which of the following apply to you?

ChoiceEle.Desc: None of these apply to me

Question.Desc: Has your provider prescribed any of the following:
Are you dependent on oxygen at all times, even at rest?
Which self-care skills do you need more information about so you can better manage your condition?

ChoiceEle.Desc: Recognizing and responding to active bleeding episodes
Maintaining an active but careful lifestyle
Wearing a medical alert ID bracelet

Question.Desc: Which of the following are true for you?

ChoiceEle.Desc: I worry that I have lost control over how much I eat
I make myself sick when I feel uncomfortably full
I have had an eating disorder in the past or have one now
I sometimes withold insulin to help me lose weight

Question.Desc: Do you use your CPAP or oral appliance as directed?
If you have pain, are you able to adequately manage it?
Have you seen/or are you seeing a wound care specialist?
Are you concerned about the person's safety?

ChoiceEle.Desc: Yes, and would like more information

Question.Desc: When did you receive your organ transplant?

ChoiceEle.Desc: Within the last 6 months or less

Has your provider prescribed an exercise therapy or physical rehab program?
Are you currently following your exercise therapy or physical rehab program?
The following preventative screening tests are recommended for you/your child. Select the tests that you need.

ChoiceEle.Desc: All recommended tests have been done or member declines to answer

Question.Desc:
NOTE: Ask the following question if this review is conducted between October 1 and March 31 AND member's age is 6 months or older.
 
Have you had a flu shot for the current (or upcoming) flu season?

ChoiceEle.Desc: Question does not apply at this time

Question.Desc: Have you EVER had the pneumococcal shot?
Have you had a Tdap (tetanus, diphtheria, and whooping cough) vaccination during this pregnancy?

Have you received the recommended HPV vaccine?

What one or two goals are most important for you to work on?

Are you willing to sign and return a paper giving us permission to share your HIV/AIDS information with your providers?

Goal.Desc: Can describe reasons for palliative care assessment

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: May I tell you about a type of medical care that is helpful for many people with a serious illness?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
This type of care, called palliative care, focuses on relieving pain and other symptoms related to a serious illness. When quality of life becomes poor and activities like bathing, dressing, and toileting requires assistance, palliative care may be appropriate. Palliative care also helps you understand your condition and your treatment options, so you can choose how you want to be treated. The goal is to improve quality of life for the person who is ill and for their family.
 
Palliative care can be provided:
  • For many different serious or chronic conditions
  • At any stage of illness
  • Along with treatment meant to cure the illness
  • By a healthcare team working with your own provider
 
Q: I would like to ask you a few questions to see if a palliative care approach might be helpful to you now or if your condition worsens. Would that be okay with you?
NOTE: If permission given, go to the Palliative Care assessment

Instruction.Desc: Discuss condition, prognosis, symptoms, symptom management, and consideration for palliative care assessment with patient/member

Intervention.Desc: If fulfillment available, offer My Choices, My Wishes

Instruction.Desc: Assist with assessment and send completed document to provider. Encourage discussion with provider.
If member agrees, complete palliative care assessment

Goal.Desc: Can describe asthma self-management and seek help when needed

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: What can you tell me about asthma?
NOTE: Praise member for correct responses
 
Asthma is a chronic lung disease that can cause shortness of breath, coughing, wheezing, and sometimes chest tightness.
 
You may have times when you don`t have any asthma symptoms at all. At other times, your symptoms may become significantly worse very quickly. This sudden or rapid worsening of your asthma symptoms is called an asthma attack, flare-up, or exacerbation. During a flare-up, symptoms may get severe very quickly and can even become life-threatening.
 
It is important to know how to manage your asthma and reduce flare-ups. An asthma attack can be quite serious, and always needs to be treated quickly. It’s also important to have a written asthma action plan, which includes specific instructions about how to treat an asthma attack. It is very important to review this part of your plan with your healthcare provider regularly
 
The goal in treating asthma is to decrease symptoms, reduce the number of flare ups, and preserve breathing capacity, thus improving the quality of your life.
Q: What questions do you have about this
 
NOTE: Answer questions. If member talks about problems or difficulties with their condition, describe how you and member can identify problems and plan next steps.

Instruction.Desc: Ask if having difficulty dealing with the stress of managing condition

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: What do you see as the benefits of using coping skills?
NOTE: Praise member for appropriate responses e.g. "That`s exactly right!"
 
Q: May I share with you why others have found that working hard to use coping skills is worth it?
NOTE: If permission given:
They have found that using coping skills may:
  • Help you gain control over stress related to <condition>
  • Decrease physical symptoms, such as pain and fatigue
  • Allow you to sleep better
  • Help you learn how your thoughts and behaviors affect your mood and outlook on life
  • Give you more confidence that you will be able to handle your health problems
  • Help improve your quality of life
 
Q: How does this fit in with your own health goals?

Many people with <condition> struggle with emotions, such as feeling stressed, discouraged, or angry. In trying to feel better, some people may do things that are not healthy, such as staying away from other people, or drinking too much alcohol. Those things are not helpful and may cause harm.
Coping skills are healthy ways to deal with stress and emotions.
Healthy things you can do to help you cope include:
  • Get regular physical activity
  • Use positive self-talk. Tell yourself: Yes, I can! My glass is half full, not half empty!
  • Do things to relax and reduce tension e.g., mental imaging, progressive muscle relaxation, or deep breathing
  • Schedule pleasant activities into your life. Do things that you have enjoyed in the past.
  • Spend time with friends and family who are supportive
  • Share your thoughts and feelings with others
  • Make tasks smaller. Break tasks down into small steps that are easier to deal with.
 
You may not feel like doing much of anything - but taking action to cope with stress and improve your mood can help you feel better.
Q: What questions do you have about this?

EducationComponent.Title: How to Recognize and Respond to Asthma Symptoms

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
It is important to be able to recognize and understand symptoms of asthma. Everyone with asthma should have a written plan with their provider ahead of time for managing symptoms. This is called an asthma action plan and helps you to know what to do when you have increased symptoms. A copy of the asthma action plan should always be kept with you. Give a copy to a close relative or friend to contact immediately if you have an asthma attack but do not have your action plan with you.
 
Manage your asthma by:
  • Pay attention to your symptoms:
    • Wheezing
    • Recurrent episodes of coughing, especially at night
    • Chest tightness
    • Difficulty breathing (feeling short of breath, or feel like can't get enough air)
    • Decreased activity – cannot do usual activities without getting short of breath
  • Use a peak flow meter:
    • As your healthcare provider told you to
    • If you have trouble recognizing when your asthma gets worse
    • Report readings in the yellow or red zone to your healthcare provider
    • Keep track of peak flow results on a chart and show the chart to your provider
  • Following the asthma action plan based on your symptoms and/or peak flow reading
 
For parents:
Children cannot always say when they are having breathing problems so an adult must watch and listen for asthma symptoms in children.
 
Asthma symptoms may include any of the following:
  • Repeated coughing, especially:
    • At night or the early morning, and/or
    • With exercise, and/or
    • With viral infections (such as colds)
  • Wheezing (a high-pitched whistling sound heard during breathing)
  • Difficulty breathing
  • An anxious look for no apparent reason
  • Speaking in short sentences or phrases only
  • New difficulty or refusal to play or be involved in activities
  • Falling peak flow meter readings (age 5 and older)
 
Additional symptoms needing immediate attention (in some cases even calling 911) include:
  • Chest retractions in children (spaces between ribs sink in when the child breathes in)
  • Rapid breathing
  • Severe difficulty breathing at rest
  • Difficulty talking
  • Peak flow meter readings in the red zone
  • Use of a rescue inhaler hasn't helped
  • Breathlessness at rest
  • Lips or fingernails are blue or gray
  • Sudden disappearance or decrease in wheezing
  • Acting agitated, confused, or drowsy
     
Your healthcare provider may instruct you to call about different symptoms
 
Keep your rescue inhaler with you to use when you need it. Always keep emergency phone numbers (healthcare provider and Nurse Advice line) on hand.
Q: Do you know what to watch for and what to do when you have asthma symptoms
If no, help problem solve.

Self-management means doing things every day to keep your asthma in good control.
 
Q: What actions do you take to manage asthma?
NOTE: Congratulate member on self-management activities.
 
Q: May I give you some tips for how to manage your asthma?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
It helps to:
  • Work as a partner with your healthcare provider. This means having regular visits, asking questions, and following your treatment or action plan
  • Have the number of your healthcare provider or the Nurse Advice line so you can call for help any time you need it
  • Pay attention to your symptoms
  • Make sure to have a written asthma action plan so that you know what to do if your symptoms get worse.
  • Take your medicines just like your healthcare provider tells you to
  • Understand how your medicine works and the side effects
  • If your healthcare has recommended you use a peak flow meter, know how and when to use it and how to respond to the measurements that it produces.
  • Avoid secondhand smoke or any asthma triggers (pollen, animals)
  • Make sure to work with your healthcare provider to manage other health conditions that affect your asthma (e.g., GERD, OSA, sinusitis, rhinitis, etc.)
 
NOTE: optional
  • It helps to know when your asthma is well controlled and when it is not. In general, your asthma is well controlled when:
    • You can do your usual activities like work, school, exercise, and sports
    • You have daytime asthma symptoms no more than 2 days a week
    • You wake up fewer times or asthma symptoms do not wake you up at night:
      • If child`s age is 5-11: Once a month or less
      • If adult or child age 12 or older: Twice a month or less
    • If monitoring peak flow: Your peak flow reading is 80% to 100% of your personal best
    • You use your rescue inhaler no more than 2 days a week
 
If your asthma is not well controlled, check to make sure you are following your asthma action plan like your provider told you to. This means knowing when to take your medicine, how and why to use a peak flow meter, and what steps to take when your symptoms start to get worse.
 
If you are following your asthma action plan, and your asthma is still not well controlled, tell your healthcare provider. You may need support on how to take your medicine or may need to take another type of medicine.
 
Q: May I tell you about some useful resources?
NOTE: If permission given, provide as much detail as needed to support member
 
These sites have many useful articles and suggestions; however, we are not affiliated with these organizations and cannot guarantee that the content or the links within them are current or accurate.
  • National Jewish Health, www.nationaljewish.org
  • American Academy of Allergy/Immunology, www.aaaai.org
  • Asthma and Allergy Foundation of America, www.aafa.org
  • National Heart Lung and Blood Institute, www.nhlbi.nih.gov
Q: What could you do to manage your asthma better?
NOTE: Review identified problems (gaps in self-management). Link improvements in self-management to achieving health goals.

Goal.Desc: Has received chronic kidney disease self-management overview

Problem.Desc: Needs chronic kidney disease self-management overview

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Chronic kidney disease is called a "silent" condition because most people don`t have symptoms until there is an advanced degree of kidney damage. Many people are diagnosed with chronic kidney disease based on the results of blood and urine tests.
 
Symptoms of chronic kidney disease may include:
  • Generalized fatigue, low energy
  • Problems sleeping
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Generalized itching
  • Headaches
  • Unintended weight loss
  • Appetite loss
  • Swelling in the hands and feet
  • Needing to urinate more or less often
 
Other conditions may also cause these symptoms, so if you have one or more of these symptoms it is important to tell your provider.
 
Healthy kidneys filter and remove waste from the blood, maintain a balance in important electrolytes in the body, and remove excess water from the blood. When kidneys are damaged, their ability to filter is affected, allowing harmful waste to build up in your body.
 
It is important to identify the cause of kidney disease. Some causes are reversible and treating these can help to prevent kidney disease from getting worse. Two of the biggest causes of chronic kidney disease are high blood pressure and diabetes. A family history of chronic kidney disease is also a risk factor.
 
Your provider will order laboratory tests to check how well your kidneys are working. There are different stages or categories of chronic kidney disease. These tests show what category you are in by how much kidney damage you have.
 
Two important tests are:
  • Blood test to check the glomerular filtration rate (GFR)
  • Urine test to measure albumin (protein). Healthy kidneys keep albumin from passing into the urine, so with this test, lower is better
     
These tests and others will be done frequently to track how well your kidneys and your treatment are working. Your provider may also order imaging tests to make sure that you do not have any blockage or kidney stones.
Chronic kidney disease affects both kidneys and can become worse over time. The kidneys can become so damaged that they cannot do the work of removing wastes and extra fluid from the body. This is called kidney failure. Treatment choices are necessary with chronic kidney disease and kidney failure. Treatment options include:
  • Dialysis: When your kidneys stop working efficiently to filter waste, you may consider dialysis, which is a treatment where a machine does the work of your kidneys. Dialysis treatments remove wastes from the blood
  • Kidney transplant: Receiving a kidney from a donor is a surgical procedure. A donor can be a friend, relative or stranger. Finding the right donor may take time. You will need to have several tests before surgery. You will also need to take medicine for the rest of your life to help prevent your body from rejecting the new kidney.
  • No treatment: If you choose no treatment or to stop treatment, death will occur in a matter of days or weeks depending on how much kidney function is left. Your medical team will offer support, counseling and medicine to keep you comfortable.
 
Chronic kidney disease can affect your health in other ways. It can cause or worsen high blood pressure. You are also more likely to have blood vessel or heart disease, bone disease, anemia and nutrition problems. Once you have been diagnosed with chronic kidney disease, it cannot be cured. The goal of treatment is to keep your kidneys as healthy as they can be for as long as possible.
Q: What questions do you have about this?

Instruction.Desc: Ask if having difficulty dealing with the stress of managing condition

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Q: What do you see as the benefits of using coping skills?
NOTE: Praise member for appropriate responses e.g. "That`s exactly right!"
 
Q: May I share with you why others have found that working hard to use coping skills is worth it?
NOTE: If permission given:
They have found that using coping skills may:
  • Help you gain control over stress related to <condition>
  • Decrease physical symptoms, such as pain and fatigue
  • Allow you to sleep better
  • Help you learn how your thoughts and behaviors affect your mood and outlook on life
  • Give you more confidence that you will be able to handle your health problems
  • Help improve your quality of life
 
Q: How does this fit in with your own health goals?

Many people with <condition> struggle with emotions, such as feeling stressed, discouraged, or angry. In trying to feel better, some people may do things that are not healthy, such as staying away from other people, or drinking too much alcohol. Those things are not helpful and may cause harm.
Coping skills are healthy ways to deal with stress and emotions.
Healthy things you can do to help you cope include:
  • Get regular physical activity
  • Use positive self-talk. Tell yourself: Yes, I can! My glass is half full, not half empty!
  • Do things to relax and reduce tension e.g., mental imaging, progressive muscle relaxation, or deep breathing
  • Schedule pleasant activities into your life. Do things that you have enjoyed in the past.
  • Spend time with friends and family who are supportive
  • Share your thoughts and feelings with others
  • Make tasks smaller. Break tasks down into small steps that are easier to deal with.
 
You may not feel like doing much of anything - but taking action to cope with stress and improve your mood can help you feel better.
Q: What questions do you have about this?

Instruction.Desc: Advise to ask provider about referral to specialist

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Taking care of yourself everyday is key to keeping yourself as healthy as possible. The day-to-day care of your <condition> is up to you.
 
If you are not sure about what things you should be doing at home to take care of yourself, it's important to ask your healthcare provider about this soon.
 
Q: Would you like some ideas on questions you can ask your healthcare provider regarding how to take care of your <condition> at home?
NOTE: If permission given:
You can ask:
  • What are the most important things I should do to take care of myself?
  • What do I monitor or test at home? How often? What do I do with the results?
  • Are there lifestyle changes, like diet or exercise that would improve my health?
  • Is there anything I need to avoid or shouldn`t do?
  • I`m afraid of (or worried about) <issue>; what should I do?
 
Q: Would you be willing to talk to your healthcare provider about ways in which you can take care of yourself at home?
Yes:
NOTE: Assist member in planning next steps
No:
NOTE: Explore using Motivational Interviewing

EducationComponent.Title: How to Self-Manage Chronic Kidney Disease

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Self-management means doing what you can to manage your chronic kidney disease and be as healthy as possible. Chronic kidney disease can get worse over time but taking care of yourself can help keep your kidneys healthier longer. It can also relieve some of your symptoms and reduce the chance that you'll have to go to the hospital.
Q: What are some things you do to take care of your kidneys?
NOTE: Congratulate member on self-management activities they are doing.
 
Q: Would you like to hear more ways to self-manage chronic kidney disease?
 
NOTE: If permission given:
Work as a partner with your provider:
  • Have regular provider visits and contact your provider with questions or problems that arise
  • Get blood and urine tests as directed
  • Learn about your test results to know how well your kidneys are working
  • Follow your treatment plan
  • Take your medicines just like your provider tells you to
  • Learn about treatment options and the types of healthcare decisions that might need to be made if your kidney disease worsens
  • Let your provider and loved ones know your preferences for medical care
 
Avoid drugs that can harm your kidneys:
  • Some medicines should not be taken, and others need to be taken in smaller doses. Ask your healthcare provider for more information
  • Avoid NSAIDs, such as ibuprofen and naproxen unless your provider tells you to take them
  • Before taking any medicines or supplements, ask your provider if they would be safe for you or if the dose needs to be adjusted
 
Manage other health conditions:
  • Keep your blood pressure in target range. For most people with chronic kidney disease, the goal is less than 130/80. High blood pressure worsens kidney damage and can lead to a heart attack or stroke
  • If diabetes: Keep your A1C in target range. High blood sugar worsens kidney damage. Your healthcare provider will advise the best A1C target for you
  • If smoker: Quit smoking. Smoking worsens kidney damage
 
Maintain a healthy diet:
  • Eat a heart-healthy diet that is low in sodium, fat, and cholesterol. Following a low sodium diet helps control your blood pressure and helps your kidneys work better. Also, people with chronic kidney disease have a higher risk of heart attack and stroke from blocked blood vessels. Eating foods low in saturated fat and cholesterol can keep cholesterol from building up in your blood vessels
  • Heart-healthy foods include vegetables, fruit, whole grains, lean meat, fish and chicken, beans, low-fat or non-fat dairy foods, and small amounts of good fats (unsaturated), such as olive oil
  • Prepare and eat food with less salt and sodium. Aim for less than 2 grams of sodium per day, unless your provider tells you differently. Check the labels on the foods that you buy to choose lower sodium options. Check with your provider before using any salt substitute
  • Eat smaller portions of protein foods, such as meat, fish, chicken, eggs, beans and dairy foods. You need some protein every day for good nutrition, but eating the right amount, rather than too much, can help protect your kidneys
  • Follow your provider's instructions for other diet changes. You may be asked to choose foods low in phosphorus and foods that are either high or low in potassium. Be aware that packaged foods and the food at restaurants may have "hidden" salt, potassium, and phosphorus
 
Be physically active:
  • Exercise for 30 minutes or more 3 to 5 times a week, for a total of 150 to 300 minutes. This is in addition to your regular activities
  • Exercise does not have to be a strenuous workout. Taking short walks twice a day can be good exercise
 
Other ways to support wellness:
  • Learn healthy ways to manage stress. If you start to feel depressed or anxious, talk to your provider about your feelings
  • Get the flu, pneumococcal and other vaccines as recommended by your healthcare provider
  • Learn more about your treatment choices for chronic kidney disease
  • If on dialysis: Learn how to safely manage your treatments. Do not skip any treatments
 
Q: Are there ways that you could take better care of yourself?
NOTE: If yes:
Q: What areas will you work on?
NOTE: Review identified problems (gaps in self-management). When possible, relate changes in self-management as way to reach member's stated health goals.

Q: May I tell you about some resources to get help that others have found useful?
NOTE: If permission given, provide as much detail as needed to support memberThese sites have many useful articles and suggestions; however, we are not affiliated with these organizations and cannot guarantee that the content or the links within them are current.
  • National Kidney Disease Education Program
    • Web: www.niddk.nih.gov
  • The National Kidney Foundation
    • Web: www.kidney.org

Goal.Desc: Has received counseling on chronic kidney disease symptom recognition

Problem.Desc: Needs counseling on chronic kidney disease symptom recognition

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Taking care of yourself includes knowing what symptoms to watch for and when to get help. This can help keep little problems from turning into big problems. It can help you stay out of the emergency room or hospital.
 
If you are not sure what to watch for and what to do, it's important to ask your provider about this soon.
Q: Would you like some ideas on questions you can ask your provider regarding symptoms to watch for?
NOTE: If permission given:
You can ask:
  • What symptoms are most important for me to watch for?
  • What am I to do if they occur?
  • What do I do if the symptoms occur during the night, on a weekend, or holiday?
  • For what types of symptoms should I call 911 or go to the emergency room?
  • I`m afraid of (or worried about) <symptom>; what should I do?
 
Q: Would you be willing to talk to your provider about symptoms to watch for and what to do about them?
Yes:
NOTE: Assist member in planning next steps
No:
NOTE: Explore using Motivational Interviewing

EducationComponent.Title: How to Recognize and Respond to Chronic Kidney Disease Symptoms

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Much of the daily care of your health is up to you. Being aware of changes in your condition and taking action right away can help keep small problems from turning into big problems. It can help prevent a visit to the emergency room or hospital.
Work with your healthcare provider and plan what to do if you have symptoms so that you can get the right treatment quickly. Contact your healthcare provider if you have signs that your condition is worsening, even when you are unsure, or signs are subtle. It`s better to let your provider know what is going on than to ignore symptoms or signs of potential problems.
Q: Would you like to hear ways to recognize worsening signs and symptoms?
NOTE: If permission given:
Signs and symptoms of worsening chronic kidney disease include:
  • Changes in urine; more or less than usual, dark or red color
  • Generalized fatigue, low energy
  • Swelling or rapid weight gain
  • Problems sleeping
  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Generalized itching
  • Headaches
  • Unintended weight loss
  • Appetite loss
  • Numbness, pain, or tingling in your hands, arms, feet, or legs
  • Unusual pain in one or both sides of the back
  • Muscle cramps or weakness
 
Q: Do you know what to watch for and what to do when you have worsening symptoms?
NOTE: If not very confident, explore and problem-solve

Intervention.Desc: If member has action plan, review

Instruction.Desc: Assess knowledge of action plan instructions

EducationComponent.Title: How to Use an Action Plan

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
NOTE: This is intended as an interactive review of member`s current action plan. Ideally, member would be looking at their action plan while discussing it.
 
Q: May I give you some tips on how to use your action plan?
NOTE: If permission given, discuss the following:
 
Availability
Your action plan is an important tool to help you take care of your <condition>. But, like any tool, if you don`t know where it is or how to use it, it isn`t very useful.
Your action plan should be kept in a place where you can easily and quickly get to it when needed.
 
Q: Where do you keep your action plan? Are you able to quickly get it when needed?
 
If child 
Q: Does the school or caregiver have a copy of the action plan?
NOTE: As needed, assist member in planning next steps to make action plan accessible
 
Understanding
Q: Tell me about your action plan. What does it tell you to watch out for? What does it tell you to do?
NOTE: As needed, assist member in planning next steps to clarify action plan instructions with provider. Consider using practice scenarios such as "If <symptom> happened, what would you do?"
 
Medications
Some people have action plans that tell them to take different medicines when they start to feel sick.
Q: What does your action plan tell you about your medicines?
 
If PRN medicines are part of action plan 
Q: Do you have a fresh supply of the medicine that you take only when you are sick? Where do you keep this medicine?
NOTE: As needed, assist member in planning next steps to obtain necessary medications. Instruct member on expiration date and storage precautions.
 
Confidence
Q: Have you ever used your action plan? If yes, tell me what happened.
Q: If needed in future, do you feel that you can follow the instructions on your action plan? NOTE: If not very confident, explore and problem-solve.

Goal.Desc: Has received counseling on chronic kidney disease monitoring tests

Problem.Desc: Needs counseling on chronic kidney disease monitoring tests

EducationComponent.Title: Understanding Chronic Kidney Disease Monitoring Tests

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Managing chronic kidney disease includes regular appointments with your provider. Your provider will ask you about your symptoms. He/she will want to know what is most bothersome to you. Your visit may include a physical exam and some tests. These tests are needed to monitor your kidney function and check for problems that can develop as a result of your condition.
 
Whenever you have a test, ask your healthcare provider the following questions:
  • What is the test?
  • What are the results?
  • What do the results mean for my treatment plan?
     
How often you need monitoring tests depends on your symptoms and the type and amount of medicine you are taking. Testing is done more often within the first year after a transplant, and in certain other situations. Having the right tests at the right time is a very important part of managing CKD.
Your tests may include:
  • Glomerular filtration rate (GFR): Measures how well your kidneys are doing their job to filter waste and excess fluid from your body
  • Complete blood count (CBC): Includes measuring hematocrit, which is the percentage of blood that consists of red blood cells. It also measures the amount of hemoglobin in the blood. Hemoglobin results tell how many red blood cells you have. A person whose blood is low in red blood cells has anemia, which is common in kidney disease. Healthy kidneys produce a hormone called erythropoietin, or EPO, which helps to produce enough red blood cells to carry oxygen to vital organs. Diseased kidneys often don`t make enough EPO, and when that happens, your provider may prescribe injections of EPO
  • Reticulocyte count: Checks the number or percent of immature red blood cells your body is producing. The results help your provider monitor and treat anemia
  • Ferritin: Is used to measure how much iron is stored in the body. If your iron level or iron storage levels are too low, EPO won`t help and you will continue to experience the effects of anemia
  • Calcium, phosphorus, parathyroid hormone (PTH), vitamin D: Checks your bone health. Bone and mineral disorders are common in patients with chronic kidney disease
  • Microalbumin: Albumin is a protein found in your blood. Kidney damage allows small amounts of this to leak into your urine. Urine albumin can be tested in two ways. One test measures the total amount of albumin. The other test compares albumin and a waste normally found in urine (creatinine)
  • Kt/V: A blood test that measures how well dialysis is cleaning your blood. A target number is determined depending on whether you are on hemodialysis or peritoneal dialysis.
  • Serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine clearance: Tests done to measure how well your kidneys filter waste
  • Blood electrolyte levels: Measures the amount of sodium, potassium, calcium, and phosphorus in your body. Damaged kidneys may not be able to regulate these minerals effectively, leading to bone disease and fluid buildup. The results also provide information about your diet
  • B12 and folate: Measure the vitamins that help your body make red blood cells. The results help your provider monitor and treat anemia
  • Bicarbonate levels: Measures the acid base status of your blood. This is used to monitor kidney function
 
It is important to have the tests your provider recommends as often as instructed. Test results help your provider monitor your condition and treatment to prevent problems and help you feel your best.
Q: What questions do you have about this?
NOTE: Answer questions. If member talks about problems or difficulties with their condition, describe how you and member can identify problems and plan next steps.

Instruction.Desc: Advise to ask provider about test results and implications for treatment

EducationComponents.EducationComponent:
Certain tests can find problems early and show how well your treatment plan is working. By having these tests at the right times and following up on the results with your provider, you can stay as healthy as possible.
 
It's important to ask your provider about <recommended test> soon.
 
Q: Would you like some ideas on questions you can ask your provider regarding this test?
NOTE: If permission given:
You can ask him/her:
  • If test recommended once: Have I had <recommended test>?
  • If test recommended periodically: Have I had <recommended test> in the past <recommended time period>?
  • If no, test not done in recommended time period:
    • Would this test be helpful for me now?
    • What will the results tell us about my condition?
    • What do I need to do to prepare for the test?
  • If yes, test was done in recommended time period:
    • Would you give me a copy of the results and explain what they mean?
    • Will there be changes in my treatment plan because of the results?
    • Are there lifestyle changes, like diet or exercise that would improve my test results?
    • When do I need to have this test again?
 
Q: Would you be willing to ask your provider about <recommended test>?
Yes:
NOTE: Assist member in planning next steps
No:
NOTE: Explore using Motivational Interviewing

Q: May I tell you about some resources to get help that others have found useful?
NOTE: If permission given, provide as much detail as needed to support memberThese sites have many useful articles and suggestions; however, we are not affiliated with these organizations and cannot guarantee that the content or the links within them are current.
  • National Kidney Disease Education Program
    • Web: www.niddk.nih.gov
  • The National Kidney Foundation
    • Web: www.kidney.org
